entry.title: Re: Method for Calculating Amounts to Be Depreciated
entry.content:
Hi @christineha ,

The main issue here is that assignment reference field is blank. You need to ensure that its always filled-up. Inorder to do so there are few controls with different options.

WorkaroundProsCons / Caveats
Ensure consistent Assignment ReferenceIf you make the “Assignment Reference” field mandatory for postings (credit memos, payments) so that it’s never blank, then the open-items will be grouped properly.Might require change to posting processes / user training / validation logic. Some legacy data might still lack that field.
User exit / BADI to populate Assignment Reference automaticallyFor example, when credit memo or unallocated payment is posted, have logic to auto-fill assignment reference (perhaps copy some other field or generate a standard ref).Requires ABAP work / approvals. Need to define what you fill in (must be consistent and meaningful).
Report / Pre-processing to identify missing recordsCreate a report to list open items missing “Assignment Reference” so that they can be corrected manually or through mass update.Still manual overhead.
Modify depreciation calculation logic (if allowed)If the depreciation calculation is custom, change it to ignore the “Assignment Reference” requirement (or treat blank as wildcard) so that all open items are included.If SAP standard logic, modifying it may not be possible or may breach upgrade safety. Need to check with SAP support whether this is allowed.
Use clearing or matching toolsClear or match items so that unallocated / credit notes become allocated and then included.May require business process changes.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos. This motivates me to serve you better.
Appreciate your feedback. Used GenAI.
Thanks,
Divyesh

entry.title: Re: Synchronization between asset master and equipment -...
entry.content:
Hi @Nina_Firus ,

Here are things you should verify, to get the workflow variant working instead of direct sync:

AreaWhat to Check / ConfigureDetails / Notes
Customizing MappingLink Asset Class ↔ Equipment Category / Object Type (table V_ANKAZ_04)Ensure mapping is unique; variant set to “Saving triggers workflow”.
Change Document ObjectsANLA → BUS1022 (Event: EQUITOBECHANGED) EQUI → EQUI (Event: ASSETTOBECHANGED)Must exist in SWEC; ensures changes (e.g., cost center) generate events.
Workflow Event LinkageSWE2 entries link events to workflows (WS3100072/73, WS3100100/101)Verify workflow start events are active and linked.
Workflow DefinitionWS3100072/73 or WS3100100/101Copy & activate SAP sample workflows; adjust to include approval steps.
Task / Agent AssignmentOAWF or PFTCAssign valid agents to tasks (e.g., TS03100055, TS03100039). Ensure agents have proper authorizations.
Equipment Workflow ActivationActivate AA sync in PM customizing“Equipment Workflow → Activate Asset Accounting (Link Object Type with Asset Class)”.
Event Activation in PMActivate workflow event for equipment categoryIf not done, system defaults to direct sync even if workflow chosen.
EnhancementsUser Exit AAPM0001 (per Note 370884)May be required for workflow-based sync; check if active/implemented.
Change Document CreationVerify in CDHDR / CDPOS for Equipment changesEnsure cost center (or relevant fields) trigger change docs, otherwise workflow won’t fire.
Monitoring / TestingUse SWEL (event trace) & workflow logConfirm events fire; if not, debug linkage.
Fallback BehaviorIf workflow config missing, system defaults to direct syncExplains why direct sync always works in your case.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos. This motivates me to serve you better.
Appreciate your feedback. Used GenAI.
Thanks,
Divyesh

entry.title: Re: Tax code rate is not displayed in Journal Entry - Cus...
entry.content:
Hi @Shrinivas ,

Generally, standard CDS views for customer correspondence typically provide Tax Code, but Tax Rate / Percentage is missing.
I guess there is no standard CDS view exposes both Tax Code + Tax Rate for intercompany invoices in Public Cloud.Try some custom options.

ApproachHow it WorksProsCons
Custom CDS View / ExtensionBuild or extend a CDS to join invoice data with tax master tables, exposing tax rate.Flexible, dynamic tax rates; reusable.Requires technical development; Cloud restrictions apply.
Extend OData ServiceAdd tax rate field into FDP_FFO_INTDOC_ENT_SRV via extensibility options.Keeps single service; direct use in form template.Public Cloud may not allow all joins; dependency on SAP’s extensibility framework.
Pre-processing / Data StorageStore tax rate in a custom field at posting time and map it to the data source.Simple retrieval in correspondence.Redundancy; must maintain tax consistency when rates change.
User Exit / Form EnhancementFetch tax rate during correspondence generation (lookup tax code → tax rate mapping).No major data model change; runtime calculation.May require ABAP/BCP work; depends on Public Cloud extensibility rules.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos. This motivates me to serve you better.
Appreciate your feedback. Used GenAI.
Thanks,
Divyesh

entry.title: Checking the Values Passed from SFSF Recruiting to SFSF Onboarding - Customers can check themselves
entry.content:
When you initiate onboarding from recruiting, more often than not, you will encounter issues where record throws an error or not all the mapped data were brought over from recruiting to onboarding.

When that happens typically the onboarding/recruiting consultant will lean on the functionality Suite Integration Test page that is available in Provisioning. Click here to review the suite integration setup functionality in SAP Help 

Provisioning access is available only to certified consultant and is not available to customers. At least till now....

In this blog post, I will show how customers can also access the Suite integration setup with accessing provisioning.

Step 1: Goto Recruiting, and select the recruiting record that you used to initiate onboarding

Candidate application profile

Step 2: Create a duplicate tab Duplicate tab with the same application profile displayed

 Step 3: In the URL, paste this URL: /xi/ui/apitest/pages/getEligibleRecordsTest.xhtml

in the browser URL. You should paste the URL right after: https://hcm41preview.sapsf.com/ (where hcm41 refers to your data center). When you do that, the suite integration setup page is displayed.

Suite integration setup page

Step 3: In the suite integration page, delete every entry before and after the "section"  Get RCM/ONB Data

 Now, delete the line "Get RCM/ONB Data". Ensure there is no blank link before "{" and after "}".

Enter the candidate profile ID in the line "candidateId"

Enter the job application id in the line "appId"

Enter the requisition id in the line "reqId"

You can leave the onboarding Id line blank

 

 Now scroll down the page, and click the option "Get Data from RCM Or ONB"

RCM-ONB response output

 The response will display data for every field you have configured in Recruit to Hire configuration step.

I am confident many HRIS colleagues on the customer side will find this link/blog to be helpful and beneficial

Shoutout: A learned colleague from SAP ONB support team showed me this trick. The colleague is not registered in the community and I am unable to provide proper credits.

entry.title: Risk is now available in SAP Cloud ALM
entry.content:
This Wednesday was the day of a bi-weekly release of features in SAP Cloud ALM, and as I follow the news continuously, I checked the “What’s new” page to see what the news for this release would be. I was happy to find a new app for Risks, which is something that was long awaited. I immediately opened Cloud ALM to check this new app. 

"What's new" page:

AI-Generated:

  • “Risk management ensures SAP projects align with business goals by proactively identifying threats to scope, budget, and timeline.
  • It transforms uncertainty into actionable insights, enabling better decision-making throughout the project lifecycle."

First, I could not find Risks in the Implementation page. I noticed a new icon, a magnifier with an exclamation mark, in the menu bar on the left side of the screen, and it was exactly the one. Clicking on that icon I could see the Risks app and created a new one to test, using the button Create.

 

I noticed that a risk has most of the fields we already use in Additional Information for other objects such as tasks, but it also has some new important fields in the context of risk management, such as Category, Mitigation Strategy and Impact/Probability (which defines the value of field Risk Level). Category and Mitigation Strategy have a list box with pre-defined values. I wonder how flexible the Category field is, since it seems to me that it could be enhanced by each customer. A risk can be assigned to project and timebox, not workstream or team, for instance. But it makes sense as it´s a project risk. But I can assign a responsible and an owner, and tag it. You can set it as a template, and its source when you create it manually is automatically set as manually created. So, I suppose soon that will be risks created from other sources, such as a Quality Gate service. Does it make sense?

Category values: 

Mitigation Strategy values:

From what I could see, the matrix for defining the Risk level based on impact and probability is like that:

The result of my first risk (just a test for this blog) is here:

After creating the risk and adding the relevant information, I could see it in the risks list. There are many filters to be used.

As this seems to be just the beginning of risk management in Cloud ALM, I didn’t find any analytics for that, nor the possibility of uploading in mass. I only found the download for analysis. Let’s follow the roadmap and wait for the next releases.

To add the Risk app in your Implementation page, go to App finder and look for it below Implementation. Flag it. In my example below I edited the Implementation page to add the app in the Design, Build, Test and Deploy section.

 

 After that you will see the app. 

Looking forward for the next steps retated to risk management, improvements to this app and analytics, and more information from the Cloud ALM team about it.

entry.title: 5C Framework for SAP Integrated Business Planning Data Validation Strategy
entry.content:
Why Data Quality in SAP IBP?

The success of SAP IBP hinges on the availability of quality data from all relevant sources across the organization. Without this foundation of high-quality data, the collaborative and cross-functional nature of IBP will be severely hampered, leading to flawed insights, poor decisions, and an ineffective planning process that fails to deliver the expected business benefits.

Therefore, organizations implementing SAP IBP must prioritize data quality initiatives as a critical component of their implementation and ongoing operations to ensure that they can leverage the full potential of the integrated planning platform. This often involves establishing data governance processes, data quality and validation routines, and ongoing monitoring of data quality across all the heterogeneous systems and departments.

I, as an IBP solution architect and consultant, have seen data quality impact on various functions and across all levels.

1. Accurate Forecasting and Demand Planning:

  • IBP heavily relies on accurate demand forecasts to plan production, inventory, and supply chain activities.
  • Poor data quality in historical sales data, market trends, or customer information will lead to inaccurate forecasts, resulting in either overstocking (leading to waste and costs) or understocking (leading to lost sales and customer dissatisfaction).

2. Reliable Supply Planning:

  • Accurate demand forecasts and reliable data on current inventory levels, lead times, and supplier capabilities are essential for effective supply planning.
  • Inaccurate data in these areas can lead to production delays, material shortages, and increased costs.

3. Effective Financial Planning:

  • IBP integrates financial planning with operational plans. Accurate financial data, including costs, revenues, and profitability, is crucial for making sound financial decisions.
  • Poor data quality can lead to inaccurate financial projections and budgets, impacting the overall financial health of the organization.

4. Informed Decision-Making:

  • IBP aims to provide a holistic view of the business, enabling informed decision- making across different departments.
  • If the underlying data is inaccurate, incomplete, or inconsistent, the insights derived from IBP will be flawed, leading to poor strategic and operational decisions.

5. Seamless Collaboration:

  • IBP fosters collaboration among different departments. Consistent and reliable data ensures that all stakeholders are working with the same information, facilitating effective communication and alignment.
  • Data quality issues can create friction and mistrust among teams, hindering the collaborative nature of IBP.

6. Performance Measurement and Improvement:

  •  IBP involves monitoring key performance indicators (KPIs) to track progress and identify areas for improvement.
  • Accurate data is essential for measuring performance accurately and identifying the root causes of any issues. Poor data quality can lead to misleading performance metrics and ineffective improvement initiatives.

Data quality is paramount for IBP success. Without high quality data, the benefits of IBP cannot be fully realized, and the organization risks making poor decisions that can negatively impact its bottom line and overall performance.

 

5C Framework for SAP IBP Data Validation

The proposed 5Cs are the core traits which determine whether the data is fit for the SAP IBP planning purpose. By adhering to these 5C's, organizations can improve their data quality, leading to more reliable insights, better decision-making, and increased operational efficiency. It is important to note that maintaining high data quality is an ongoing process that requires continuous monitoring and improvement.

  1. Conformity
  2. Consistency
  3. Completeness
  4. Comprehensiveness
  5. Concurrency

Figure 1: 5Cs of Data Quality Framework

1.      Conformity

This aspect of the SAP IBP data quality ensures that data adheres to predefined rules and standards regarding format, type, and size.

  1. Case for the predefined rules: In SAP IBP there are predefined special characters which cannot be used. (Refer to SAP note: 2453887)

Figure 2: SAP Note 2453887 listing restricted characters

b. Case for the format, type, and size: In SAP IBP, each attribute that exists has a format, type and size associated. All the value must comply by the formats, types, and sizes otherwise there is a risk of the job failure with fatal error.

FORMAT TYPESIZE
NVARCHAR (with/without Only Upper Case)  Character Length (max length up to 450)
DECIMAL    18,6
INTEGER      Whole Number
TIMESTAMP        YYYYMMDD hh:mm:ss.000

Table 1: SAP IBP Format Types and Sizes

2.      Consistency

This aspect of the SAP IBP data quality ensures uniformity, coherency, and avoidance of contradictions across different data sources, planning areas, data objects and time periods. Consistency ensures that information is uniform and comparable throughout the organization. However, when SAP IBP receives data from multiple sources such as ERP systems, data warehouses, cloud-based data lakes, third-party systems, home-grown applications, production planning system, transport planning system and planners' Excel sheets, maintaining data consistency becomes key area to focus on. This diversity of data sources, if ignored, can lead to discrepancies in data formats, definitions, and quality, potentially compromising the accuracy of SAP IBP's planning processes.

To ensure consistency in master Data SAP IBP provides some in-build checks which must be configured like attribute checks and mandatory attributes.

Figure 3: IBP Master Data object consistency checks with attribute checks

For IBP transactional data, we can ensure consistency by adding a mandatory attribute from compound master data in planning level for the key figure. Such configuration avoids inconsistent transactional data flowing into the system.

Figure 4: IBP mandatory attribute used in base planning level of key figures

It is important to understand that SAP IBP does not inherently guarantee consistency within object hierarchies such as Product, Customer, and Location hierarchies. Therefore, the Customer and System Integrator's consultants must collaboratively develop a strategy to ensure consistency in parent-child relationships (1:N cardinality) for hierarchical data objects. This proactive approach is crucial for accurate aggregation and disaggregation, enabling effective and actionable insights.

Figure 5: IBP Data Hierarchy with Parent Child relationship

To ensure the correct parent-child relationships, one of the approaches is to extract a parent-child combination in excel sheet and create a pivot table on unique records. All children must have single parent otherwise aggregation and disaggregation will be wrong, leading to wrong planning results.

3.      Completeness

The completeness of data refers to the state where all the necessary and relevant data points required for the specific planning process and the overall IBP framework are present and available within the system. It means that there are no significant gaps or missing pieces of information that hinder the ability to perform accurate analysis, generate reliable plan and make informed decisions.

Figure 6: Incomplete/Broken Supply Network

Figure 6 clearly demonstrates the incompleteness of the data from the supply chain network where capacity data at resource is missing along with a broken network with respect to missing lanes. Such an incomplete dataset will generate improper planning results.

To avoid the incomplete data flowing into the IBP system, we need to develop interfaces outside the IBP system using ABAP validations in SAP S4 or BW4HANA or CIDS to identify the incompleteness and generate a report for correction by clients IT Team / Data Management Team. By using the "Manage Rules for Master Data Maintenance" feature in IBP, we can effectively define the correct "Subnetwork" node and diagnose which node is disrupting the supply chain network. Example: All Location product combinations to pass through following checks updating a corresponding custom attribute which finally impacts the subnetwork.

1.Inbound: Master data rule to check for Location source in Location Source object.

2.Inbound: Master data rule to check source production in Source Production Header object.

3.Outbound: Master data rule to check Ship-from with product combination in Location Source object.

4.Outbound: Master data rule to check Location Product combination in Source Customer object.

5.Outbound: Master data rule to check Location Product combination in production source Item.

* This is just an approach which may differ from project to project and network schema variations.

4.      Comprehensiveness

Data Comprehensiveness refers to the degree to which all the necessary and relevant data required to support the IBP processes, models, and overall planning objectives is available, accessible, and integrated within the IBP system. It goes beyond just having completeness. It entails:

  • Breadth of Data: Having data across all relevant dimensions and business areas that are within the scope of the IBP implementation. This includes data related to sales, demand, supply, inventory, finance, and potentially other relevant areas.
  • Depth of Data: Having data at the appropriate level of detail required for the planning activities, ensuring that data is available for all the products, customers, locations, and other relevant entities that are included in the IBP planning scope.

Figure 7: Data Comprehensiveness covers all the IBP data objects including each attribute

Example for missing comprehensiveness can be missing key attribute values like Lead Times, Lot Sizes, rounding values, Quota split ratios, Cost rates, On-hand Inventory for few combinations only in IBP system. It may cause unreliable planning results. To systematically capture all such cases, IBP custom alerts can be valuable to report missing attributes. Along with this the IBP’s feature like “Discover Pattern using Machine Learning”, “Find Numerical Outliers” can help identify the completeness gaps.

Figure 8: IBP Feature for data pattern discovery and numeric outliers

5.      Concurrency

Every business executive stives to strike alignment between business strategic planning and execution system. Concurrency in planning and execution represents a paradigm shift from traditional sequential approaches, enabling organizations to adapt dynamically in fast-paced environments. This methodology interweaves planning and action in real time, allowing adjustments based on evolving conditions while maintaining operational continuity. The planning and execution should be coupled like Yin-Yang.

Figure 9: Yin-Yang of Planning and Execution

From IBP planning perspective the concurrency is achieved while keeping it updated with the latest execution data. The execution data represents the latest customer orders, internal goods movements between Plants and RDCs, latest production orders, and vendor related purchase orders are integrated daily or even lesser frequency to IBP. This enables IBP planners to have complete visibility of the execution system, and they can align the plan or coordinate with execution teams to keep working on the same organizational objective.

Conclusive Remarks

At its core, the success of SAP IBP depends entirely on high-quality data. Without a solid foundation of accurate, reliable information, the platform's ability to facilitate collaboration and integrated planning is undermined. This leads to flawed insights, poor decision-making, and ultimately, a failure to deliver the expected business benefits.

Key impacts of poor data quality include:

  • Inaccurate forecasting and supply planning, resulting in issues like over- or under-stocking.

  • Flawed financial planning and projections.

  • Uninformed decisions because the underlying data is inconsistent or incomplete.

  • Friction among teams due to a lack of trust in shared data.

  • Misleading performance metrics, which hinder effective improvement initiatives.

Therefore, prioritizing data quality through robust governance, validation, and monitoring is not just a best practice—it's essential for organizations to fully leverage SAP IBP's potential. The 5C Validation Framework (Conformity, Consistency, Completeness, Comprehensiveness, Concurrency) provides a core set of traits to ensure data is fit for purpose, leading to more reliable insights and greater operational efficiency.

References

    1. Article by Spyrodon D. Tsolas, M.M. Faruque Hsan, “Survivability‐aware design and optimization of distributed supply chain networks in the post COVID‐19 era”, Journal of Advanced Manufacturing and Processing , June 2021
    2. https://www.linkedin.com/pulse/sap-ibp-explained-how-integrated-planning-technology-shaping-pandey-fyarf/
    3. https://learning.sap.com/learning-journeys/exploring-planning-processes-in-sap-ibp/sap-best-practices-for-sap-ibp
    4. https://learning.sap.com/learning-journeys/discovering-sap-ibp-for-inventory-planning-and-optimization/understanding-key-differentiators-of-sap-integrated-business-planning-for-inventory
    5. https://www.linkedin.com/pulse/understanding-difference-between-planning-executing-systems-spires-d3fnc/

entry.title: Re: ECC6 upgrade operating system and database
entry.content:
Hi,

As per the screenshot, you are using SAP NW version 7.01 SP level 07. To run Windows 2019 with MS SQL 2019, a minimum SP level of 18 is required, as per SAP Note 2807743. On the existing SAP system, you need to upgrade the SP level and begin migrating the system to a new environment.

Regards

SS

entry.title: Join Us at SAP Connect in Las Vegas – Discover the Future of AI-Driven Customer Experience
entry.content:

SAP Connect 2025 is right around the corner, and we’re excited to showcase how AI, proactive support, services, and innovative cloud solutions are shaping the future of customer experience (CX).

👉 Don’t miss your chance to join inspiring sessions hosted by SAP Services and Support experts, customers, and partners. Gain hands-on insights into how leading organizations are driving resilience, scalability, and business impact with SAP solutions.

Here are some highlights from the Customer Experience track:

📅Tuesday, October 7, 2025

2:00 – 2:20 PM PDT | Fontainebleau | CXP2030
Proactive, AI-driven support for resilient customer experiences
Speakers: Stefan Steinle (SAP) & Josh Sala (Meijer)
Discover how Meijer leverages AI to move from reactive to proactive support, boosting availability, compliance, and customer trust.

10:00 – 10:45 AM PDT | Fontainebleau | CXP2041
Fast-tracking business AI with a winning CX AI adoption strategy
Speaker: Rajeev Ranjan (SAP)
Learn how SAP Preferred Success, agentic AI, and embedded copilots like Joule bridge the AI adoption gap and deliver real value.

10:30 – 10:50 AM PDT | Fontainebleau | CXP1149
AI-driven system resilience: Enabling uptime and business continuity
Speakers: Tarun Luthra (SAP) & Suhaim Mohamed (Douglas)
Hear how Douglas ensures 100% uptime during retail peaks with predictive AI-driven support.

entry.title: Re: Build Process automation approval form request isn’t...
entry.content:
Please have a look at Guidelines for Specifying Recipient Users 

User Name of the shadow user created in the account has to be match exactly what is mentioned as recipient user. 

Most reliable way is to provision the shadow users and not allow for automatic shadow user creation. 

if you allow for automatic shadow user creation, User Name of the created shadow user is many times out of your control. To make matters worse, recently, Work Zone started creating shadow users with Global User ID of the user from IAS as the User Name.

entry.title: How to add BW Last Data Update field to SAP Analytics Cloud + Datasphere (SAP Note 2706430)
entry.content:
Summary

SAP Note 2706430 - How to get latest datasource update/refresh data date/time in SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC)?
Improvement Request 219791 - Dynamic text for datasource last refresh date and time

When customers move from SAP BW to SAP Datasphere + SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC), a common ask is: “Where’s the BW-style Last Data Update field?” SAC’s dynamic-text / model metadata doesn’t reliably supply a full source refresh timestamp for all scenarios, so the recommended pattern is to capture the refresh timestamp at the source (or during the import/persistence flow), expose it through a small tracking table / SQL view and then surface it in the SAC story via dynamic text on a small analytic model. This post shows a practical, production-ready approach and pitfalls to watch out for.

 

Introduction

Customers migrating from SAP Business Warehouse (BW) often miss the metadata field “Last Data Update” that shows when a dataset was last refreshed. BW had the table RSDINFOPROVDATA to store that info for each BW data cube— in Datasphere/HANA + SAC we can recreate this pattern. This post explains a reproducible approach:

  1. discover the underlying tables/views for your Analytical Model (lineage),
  2. create a small refresh-tracking table,
  3. populate it during your delta-import, import or persistence flows
  4. combine tracked records using a SQL View, and
  5. expose it to SAC using a tiny analytic model
  6. consume the information using a dynamic text filed in your story

 

1) Find the source objects 

Use Datasphere / HANA lineage features (calculation view lineage) or the HANA system view OBJECT_DEPENDENCIES to find which base tables feed your Analytical Model / calculation view. Example SQL to use in HANA Database Explore:

SELECT TOP 1000000
  "BASE_DATABASE_SCHEMA_NAME",
  "BASE_DATABASE_NAME",
  "BASE_SCHEMA_NAME",
  "BASE_OBJECT_NAME",
  "BASE_OBJECT_TYPE",
  "DEPENDENT_DATABASE_NAME",
  "DEPENDENT_SCHEMA_NAME",
  "DEPENDENT_OBJECT_NAME",
  "DEPENDENT_OBJECT_TYPE",
  "DEPENDENCY_TYPE"
FROM "PUBLIC"."OBJECT_DEPENDENCIES"
WHERE "DEPENDENT_SCHEMA_NAME" = '<SPACE_NAME>'
  AND "DEPENDENT_OBJECT_NAME" LIKE '<Analytical_Model_Name>%'
  AND "BASE_OBJECT_TYPE" = 'TABLE';

This gives you the base tables that the model depends on. if you have multiple analyitc models it is a best practise to group these where possible.

 

2) Create a tracking table (“RSDINFOPROVDATA” equivalent)

Create a small table to capture last refresh timestamps for each tracked table. I recommend to enable it for Delta capture.

When Importing data across different spaces you need to create multiple tables since shared tables are read only. These tables can later be joined in step 4.

 

3) Populate the tracking table during data import/ persistence

Pattern A — Import using delta tables

If you have delta tables (e.g., <TABLE>_Delta), use a transformation flow to compute the latest timestamp and upsert it into 1TL_Last_Delta.

Example SQL used by a transformation flow:

SELECT t."View_Name", t."Last_Refresh" FROM "<DELTA TABLE>" t 
WHERE "View_Name" IN ('<TRACKED TABLE 1>', '<TRACKED TABLE 2>', '<TRACKED TABLE 3>', '<TRACKED TABLE 4>') 
UNION ALL 
SELECT 'MAX_<TRACKED TABLE 1>_<TRACKED TABLE 2>' AS "View_Name", MAX(t."Last_Refresh") AS "Last_Refresh" FROM "<DELTA TABLE>" t 
WHERE t."View_Name" IN ( '<TRACKED TABLE 1>', '<TRACKED TABLE 2>' )

Schedule this transformation flow according to how fresh you need the timestamp. A typical balance is hourly — fine-grained enough for most BI needs but light on compute. (If you need real-time, use the import chains that run on every update; see Pattern B below.)

Pattern B — Import using a task chain and table persistence

If you use a task chain to import or persist tables, attach a final transformation step that writes the current timestamp / last-change value to 1TL_Last_Delta. For persisted tables you can also read the “<TABLE>_Delta” tables using a transformation flow to determine last modification time. Careful this may lead to false information incase you persist your data without checking if new data is available.

 

4) Combine tracked data into a single SQL view your model can consume

You may have to join or union several tables or tracked objects (for a model that depends on multiple tables). Example view:

SELECT
  t."VIEW_NAME",
  t."LAST_REFRESH"
FROM "<SPACE_NAME>"."TRACK_REFRESH" t
WHERE t."VIEW_NAME" IN ('<TRACKED_TABLE_1>', '<TRACKED_TABLE_2>', '<TRACKED_TABLE_3>')
UNION ALL
-- optional: an aggregated row (MAX of two tracked tables)
SELECT
  'MAX_<TRACKED_TABLE_1>_<TRACKED_TABLE_2>' AS "VIEW_NAME",
  MAX(t."LAST_REFRESH") AS "LAST_REFRESH"
FROM "<SPACE_NAME>"."TRACK_REFRESH" t
WHERE t."VIEW_NAME" IN ('<TRACKED_TABLE_1>', '<TRACKED_TABLE_2>')

 

 

5) Expose to SAP Analytics Cloud

Option A — Single analytic model with a View_Name variable (recommended)

  • Create a Datasphere Analytic Model that exposes the view created in step 4 and add a filter variable View_Name.
  • In the SAC story, set the variable to the name of the table your story is dependent on. Then add dynamic text that references the Last_Refresh value.

Pros: fewer models to maintain, single point of truth.
Cons: depends on how well story variables persist and on your story variable settings for bookmarks; if your story must clear variables on load, you may use the pattern below.

Option B — One analytic model per story / analytic model

If you cannot rely on story-level variables (for example if your stories use “Clear Variables and Use Server-Defined Values” or bookmarks that clear variables), create a small analytic model per story or analytic model that already filters to the “VIEW_NAME”-value that story needs.

Pros: deterministic for each story/leading table and avoids variable state issues or user from changing the variable.
Cons: model overhead with poor maintainability.

Option C — Integration in existing analytic model

If you cannot rely on story-level variables (for example if your stories use “Clear Variables and Use Server-Defined Values” or bookmarks that clear variables), you can also integrate the timestamps in the existing analytical model. this may be more difficult in complex analytic models and produces excess data and is poor to maintain!

 

6) Display in SAC story

Once the LAST_REFRESH is available as a dimension in your SAC Story you can add a text box to the story and Insert → Dynamic Text → Dimension → choose <ANALYICAL_MODEL> → choose “Last Refresh”. Also make sure to configure the filter accordingly to step 5.

I recommend using "Last Updated" for Pattern A and "Data Current as of" for Pattern B from step 3.

 

References

  • Add Dynamic Text to a Story  SAP Help Portal
  • Set Story Variables SAP Help Portal
  • OBJECT_DEPENDENCIES System View (HANA Cloud SQL reference) SAP Help Portal
  • Community thread discussing “get latest datasource update/refresh” SAP Community
  • SAP Note 2706430 - How to get latest datasource update/refresh data date/time in SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC)
  • Improvement Request 219791 - Dynamic text for datasource last refresh date and time

entry.title: Error on account assignment (ME21N)
entry.content:
Please help!!!
Issue:
In the system, there is an addon program Z2. Users use this addon to upload a file in order to create a flow SO → PR → PO.
The file upload contains material code, internal order no., etc.

  • On PRD of the old version (1909), it runs without any issues.

  • On QAS of the new version (2023), error KI249 (Enter only one true account assignment) occurs at the PO creation step.

Investigation result:

  • On QAS of the new version: when creating the SO, the internal order was not entered, so the profit center was derived based on the business area.
    When creating the PO, the internal order is taken from the uploaded file. The profit center linked to the internal order is different from the profit center on the SO. When saving, error KI249 is raised.

  • On PRD of the old version: the profit center taken from the internal order is also different from the profit center derived from the business area on the SO, but no error occurred.

⇒ Why does the same operation trigger an error in one environment but not in the other? Where should we check to compare the configuration between the two environments?

entry.title: Session 1 Recap & Highlight - SAP BDC The Future of Intelligent Data Architectures 🚀
entry.content:
Why SAP Invested in BDC 💡

The journey started with SAP’s recognition of a growing "context gap" in enterprise data—which emerges when organizations must stitch together SAP and non-SAP data across disparate platforms (think Databricks, Snowflake, Microsoft Fabric). Without business context, analytics and AI initiatives often struggle to deliver real value. BDC was built to close this gap by harmonizing and managing all enterprise data—structured, semi-structured, SAP, and non-SAP—in a unified, semantically enriched way.

 

What Sets BDC Apart? 🎯

  • Automation First: BDC flips the script on traditional data management, automating data curation and harmonization. Instead of endless upfront effort, customers get ready-to-consume, semantically rich data products—saving time and reducing what SAP calls the “hidden data tax”.
  • Data Product Model: SAP identifies “primary data products” (like finance, supply chain, HR) and brings them directly from SAP applications into BDC, curated and cataloged for instant use. The goal is to reach 500 data products by year-end—covering virtually every major enterprise domain.
  • AI-Ready Fabric: BDC’s lakehouse architecture and built-in “business fabric” layer empower businesses to use advanced analytics, natural language queries, and AI seamlessly. Dual integration and knowledge graph support mean both applications and users can access harmonized, context-rich insights.

 

Interoperability & Ecosystem 🌐

  • BDC Connect: This technology helps integrate BDC with non-SAP systems like Databricks, enabling zero-copy data sharing and harmonized catalogs—perfect for hybrid and multicloud enterprises.
  • Marketplace Vision: SAP is launching a data products marketplace, encouraging partners and customers to publish, consume, and innovate with SAP and non-SAP data. The upcoming announcement at SAP Connect will explain how the ecosystem and intelligent apps can grow—most delivered by partners, not just SAP.

 

Data Democratization: Empowering Every Employee 👥

Pinar described SAP’s internal rollout—“customer zero”—where business users, not just IT, access BDC’s data products and build dashboards in hours. This isn’t just technology; SAP orchestrates enablement cohorts, training citizen analysts to maximize value and foster data-driven decision making at every level.

  • Reusable Data Products: Designed for broad, multi-use case consumption, not one-off analytics. Both IT and business users (citizen analysts) can build, extend, and share data-driven solutions thanks to low-code/no-code tooling.
  • Enablement & Governance: SAP couples technology with strong governance and enablement programs—using Collibra for cataloging, trust-building, and making metadata as easy to navigate as grocery shopping.

 

 

🌍Whether you’re an enterprise architect, citizen analyst, or just curious about the future of business intelligence—SAP Business Data Cloud delivers a new foundation for turning data into real business outcomes, faster and smarter than ever before.

🙋‍♂️ Which BDC feature excites you most? Are you ready for data democratization in your organization? Share your thoughts below!

Note: Slides from the session and the recording would be only available to the registered attendees. So if you have not registered, please register now using the link below:

https://events.sap.com/eaa-bdc-apac/en_us/home.html#accordion-5d79451476-item-9ff3b2b36e

 

Important links 🔗

  1. Architecture Center: https://architecture.learning.sap.com/
  2. Enterprise Architect Learning Journey: https://learning.sap.com/learning-journeys/discovering-sap-enterprise-architecture
  3. SAP Business Data Cloud Learning Journey: https://learning.sap.com/courses/introducing-sap-business-data-cloud

entry.title: Balance Validation accelerating the period closing by Superb validation, automation and analytics
entry.content:
Join us for co-innovation

We would like to invite the public cloud customers joining us for the co-innovation of AI capability AI assisted Balance Validation Rule Creation, and if you are with valid FBA, please feel free to reply me in this blog, and we are looking forward meeting you.

Let's shape the future together. 

Challenge

Organizations often face challenges such as a financial close process that struggles to reach peak performance, characterized by inefficiencies and delayed timelines. Additionally, governance and compliance requirements can become overly burdensome, consuming valuable time with extensive data collection and documentation efforts. Furthermore, there is frequently a lack of transparency and insight across system boundaries, which hampers decision-making and collaboration. Tackling these issues requires a strategic approach that involves process optimization, technology adoption, and fostering a culture of collaboration and continuous improvement.

Key capabilities in financial management systems are designed to enhance accuracy, efficiency, and communication.

  • Managing validation rules and groups standardizes these processes, preventing financial misstatements and reducing audit and compliance risks.
  • Automated balance validation tasks accelerate the closing process and minimize manual efforts, freeing up valuable time for strategic activities.
  • Real-time validation analytics provide immediate insights and maintain a comprehensive audit trail, ensuring transparency and accountability.
  • The ability to add comments facilitates smooth communication between subsidiaries and headquarters, ensuring alignment and reducing misunderstandings. Together, these capabilities transform financial operations, driving reliability and efficiency.

Balance Validation plays a critical role in supporting Accounting and Group Reporting, especially when integrated with Advanced Financial Closing processes. This function ensures that all accounts are accurately reconciled and validated, providing a strong foundation for precise financial reporting. By incorporating Balance Validation into the closing cycle, organizations can identify discrepancies early, reduce errors, and enhance the integrity of their financial statements. This integration not only accelerates the closing process but also strengthens group reporting by ensuring consistent and reliable data across all levels of the organization, thereby supporting compliance and informed strategic decision-making.

The application of Manage Balance Validation Rules and Groups provides a centralized platform for defining and managing validation rules that prevent financial misstatements and mitigate compliance risks. 

The application Scheduled Balance Validation Jobs accelerates the financial closing cycle while significantly reducing manual workload by automating balance validation tasks. 

The application View Balance Validation Results offers immediate insights and maintains an audit trail, ensuring transparency. Furthermore, it facilitates seamless communication between subsidiaries and headquarters, ensuring alignment and effective coordination across all financial activities.

Roadmap

We will provide AI assisted Balance Validation Rule Creation on S/4HANA Public Cloud to empower business users by simplifying the rule definition process, enhancing flexibility, and improving responsiveness to customer-specific requirements, reducing the dependency on business process experts.

Users initiate requests using straightforward business language. The AI then analyzes historical data and industry best practices to draft a proposed validation rule, incorporating common elements such as G/L account hierarchy nodes and function areas. This intelligent proposal streamlines the rule creation process, minimizing the need for specialized expertise. Users can subsequently review the draft, make necessary adjustments, and save or activate the rule, ensuring it aligns with organizational requirements and enhances the accuracy and efficiency of financial operations.


 

 

Here is the help document about Balance Validation capability,

Balance Validation | SAP Help Portal

entry.title: How to configure SAML SSO for SAP HANA Cockpit -with Database Groups&Resource Ids as SAML Attributes
entry.content:
Prerequisites:

  • SAP HANA Cockpit has been installed and running.
  • An administration account in SAP HANA Cockpit is available, i.e. COCKPIT_ADMIN.
  • Identity Provider service application is available for use. 

Procedures:

Section 1. Preparation in HANA Cockpit Manager

In this section, you may consider creating or assigning expected database groups and registered database resources for IdP users.

  1. Open HANA Cockpit Manager with an administration user, i.e. COCKPIT_ADMIN or XSA_ADMIN, navigate to “Database Groups”.

  2. Create database groups and assign Databases to the group.



  3. Note down the Resource IDs (ResID) of the Databases that the IdP user is expected to access.
    Go to Registered Databases – Select the Database resource and find the ResID at the end of the URL.


    In above screenshot, ResID = 49623.

     

Section 2. (Optional) Configuration in SAP Cloud Identity Service Part I - User setup

  1. Note: If the user is expected to access all database groups, then you can skip this section.
    Configure user attributes
    1. In SAP IDS, click Menu Tab “Users & Authorizations” – select “User Management”



    2. Search for the IdP user account, click to open the user configuration.
      Verify whether there’s correct email address maintained.
    3. Expend the drop-down of “Details”, click to navigate to “Custom Attributes”

    4. Enter the Database Group Name of this user in “Custom Attribute 1”. E.g. SYSTEMDBs



    5. To specify Database Resources, enter the ResID (resource ID) of each database resources, delimited by comma in “Custom Attribute 2”.  The ResID can be found in the way introduced in Section 1 – Step 3.

      For example, 49623 for SYSTEMDB@H78.

      • If multiple database groups or resources need to be mapped, use comma-separated list without spaces.



      • If the user expects to enter all Database Resources under this Database Group, leave the “Custom Attribute 2” as blank.

Section 3. Configuration in SAP Cloud Identity Service Part II – Setup Groups and Download Metadata

In this documentation, we use SAP Cloud Identity Service (SAP IDS) as Identity Provider, you can also use other IdP alternatively.

  1. Groups Setup
    1. Access SAP Cloud Identity Service, create “Groups” under “Users & Authorizations”.


      Create below Groups.
      • HANA_COCKPIT_USER
      • IDP_USER
      • HANA_COCKPIT_ADMIN
      • HANA_COCKPIT_RESOURCE_ADMIN
      • HANA_COCKPIT_USER_ADMIN
      • HANA_COCKPIT_POWER_USER





    2. After creating the Groups, your account can be seen as a member of the group.



      As administrator, the authorizations of the IDP user can be controlled by assigning different groups to the user.
      You can access User Management, search for the user ID, and open the Groups tab.

      *The creation (and mapping) of Groups depends on the corresponding Role collections that the IDP user expects.





      For example, a user is able to access HANA Cockpit with specific Database Group or Resources with below Groups assigned.
      • HANA_COCKPIT_USER
      • IDP_USER

  2. Download the metadata of the Identity Provider service.
    1. Go to “Applications & Resources” – “Tenant Settings”



    2. Select “Single Sign-On” – “SAML 2.0 Configuration”



    3. Click “Download Metadata File” and save the Metadata File to local.

Section 4. Configuration in XSA Cockpit

  1. Open the XSA Cockpit in web browser.
    The url can either be found from the API URL:




    Or it can be found from the xs apps list:



    Login as an administration account, e.g. COCKPIT_ADMIN or XSA_ADMIN.

  2. (Optional) Create IDP Role, Role Collection and Role Mappings
    Note: If there’s no requirement for IDP user to access HANA Cockpit with specific Database Groups and Resources, then you can pass this step.
    1. Navigate to left menu bar Security – Role Collections – New Role Collection
      Name: IDP_USER



      Currently, there’s no Role assigned to it.

    2. Navigate to left menu bar Organizations – E.g. HANACockpit – the Space where Cockpit installed, E.g. SAP, find Application cockpit-persistence-svc, click to open the configuration of this Application.



    3. Navigate the left menu bar Security – Roles, create a new Role.



      Name: IDP_USER
      Template: COCKPIT_IDP_USER
      Attributes:
      ResourceGroups  - Identity Provider (SAML) – ResourceGroups
      Resources - Identity Provider (SAML) – Resources



      Save.

    4.  

      Assign this Role to the Role Collection
      You can see the Role IDP_USER just collected, click the “+” button.



      Select IDP_USER Role Collection which we created in Step 2.a.  And Save.



  3. Create IdP Trust Configuration
    1. Go to the Home page of XSA Cockpit, e.g. Click “Home”.



    2. Navigate to left menu bar “Security” – “IdP Trust Configuration” – Click “New Trust Configuration”



    3. Click the “Upload” button and upload the IdP Metadata xml file downloaded in Section 3 – Step 2.c.


      No need for other modification at this step. Then Save.

  4. Create Role Mappings
    1. Click to enter the Identity Provider just created. Navigate to “Role Collection Mappings”





    2. Create New Rolle Collection Mapping to map the Role Collection to the Groups create in SAP Cloud Identity Service in Section 3 - Step 1.





      For other Groups, the Role Collection Mappings are as below:



  5. Download SAP HANA Cockpit metadata.
    1. Go back to “Security” – “IdP Trust Configuration”, click “Show UAA trust metadata”



    2. Copy and paste the content to local and save as .xml, E.g. Cockpit_Metadata.xml

There’s another way to download the SAP HANA Cockpit metadata, which is to open below URL directly in web browser.
https://<fqdn>:3<instance number>32/uaa-security/saml/metadata

Section 5. Configuration in SAP Cloud Identity Service Part III – IdP setup

  1. Create Application for SAP HANA Cockpit in SAP IDS
    1. Open the Identity Provider service, access “Applications & Resources” – Applications



    2. Create your Application for SAP HANA Cockpit



    3. In the Application, click “SAML 2.0 Configuration” under Trust tab – Single Sign-On section



    4. Import the metadata of SAP HANA Cockpit
      Click “Upload Metadata”



    5. Select the metadata .xml file, i.e. Cockpit_Metadata.xml downloaded in Section 4 - Step 5. Download SAP HANA Cockpit Metadata, and “Upload”. No need to maintain the Endpoints.



  2. Configure the Subject Name Identifier
    1. Go back to the Application created for SAP HANA Cockpit, click to enter “Subject Name Identifier” under Trust tab – Single Sign-On section.



    2. Set the Primary Attribute as
      Source: Identity Directory
      Value: Email



  3. Configure IdP Attributes
    1. Go back to the Application for SAP HANA Cockpit, click to enter “Attributes”.



    2. Add Attribute - Groups
      Name: Groups
      Source: select “Identity Directory”
      Value: select “All Groups” from the drop-down list



    3. Add Attribute - ResourceGroups
      Name: ResourceGroups
      Source: select “Expression”
      Value: enter “${customAttribute1}”

    4. Add Attribute - Resources
      Name: Resources
      Source: select “Expression”
      Value: enter “${customAttribute2}”

      Then “Save”.

Now all configuration is done, you can test the SAML SSO by launching SAP HANA Cockpit and single sign-on with IdP. Then the mapped database group is shown on top of other tiles.

entry.title: Re: SAP Datasphere - Architecture and Lessons-Learned
entry.content:
Thanks for sharing your experience, and for the very neat blog!
What I like spaces for, especially segregating them by SAP modules, when it's the primary Source System in a 2-3 tier landscape:
> They force developers to think where to put the objects and who takes the ownership.
> The lineage visibility is much more clear.
> They force developers to analyse dependencies between transport packages and communicate.
> Segregation of storage, compute, connections.
> Service approach, isolation, authorizations.
What I don't like:
< Not being able to easily join cross-space views from the Database Explorer.
< Maintenance. 

I have some thoughts about putting Fact Views in the reporting layer and not propagation too, but that maybe for another time.

Cheers!

entry.title: Re: Support for Base64-Encoded Fingerprints in SFTP Adapter
entry.content:
@CCSAPCEPSA 

If you are on SP33 Patch 0 or Patch 1, you must configure the fingerprint in Base64 format (e.g., SHA256:xxxxxx…) for the scenario to work, since the server provides the fingerprint in this format. However, any existing scenarios with fingerprints configured in hexadecimal format will fail during fingerprint validation.

The enhancement described in SAP Note 3652688 is available starting from SP33 Patch 2. With this change, fingerprints configured in hexadecimal format (with or without MD5/SHA1 prefix) will work without issues. If you want to use Base64 format fingerprints, you must explicitly configure them in the channel and set the parameter useBase64Fingerprint to true.

entry.title: Re: Exporting SAP Tables with SLT to MS-SQL Server or AWS official documentation
entry.content:
To replicate into DB not supported by SAP you need to use SLT SDK where implement own logic.  See https://launchpad.support.sap.com/#/notes/2652704
If you would like to replicate data into MS SQL Server you can use standard implementation delivered with SLT ADDON. You nee to configure DB connection to MSSQL and in SLT create configuration choosing this DB connection as target.

entry.title: Re: Use case of MMRV
entry.content:
Hello @KARTHIK-G 

That's right - MMRV switches on/off postings to a previous period:

A typical business case of such backpostings is that not all MM postings are entered into the system in real time. For instance receipts from production may be posted in real time, they might be automatically posted by a MES system. Therefore production needs a new period opened at the very beginning of a month. However other postings might be entered with a delay, for instance office supplies receipts might be posted only during working days, not on weekends.

Best regards

Dominik Tylczynski

entry.title: Re: The SIC URL does not authenticate username and password
entry.content:
Please refer to KBA 3310759 - Revised Authorization Concept for SAP Readiness Check 

To access SAP Readiness Check on SAP for Me [ https://me.sap.com/readinesscheck ], S-user need below authorizations:

  • Display SAP Readiness Check Analysis: Enables S-users to view all SAP Readiness Check analyses belonging to the customer number associated with their user ID.

  • Manage SAP Readiness Check Analysis: Enables S-users to create, edit, delete, and share all SAP Readiness Check analyses belonging to their customer number.

    Please contact your super admin to ask for relevant authorizations then have a try again
